meanings.def: to put powder, lipstick, etc. on your/somebody’s face to make it more attractive or to prepare for an appearance in the theatre, on television, etc.

examples: Women make up 56 per cent of the student numbers.
be made up of something The course is made up of 12 two-hour sessions.

meanings.def: to put something together from several different things
to invent a story, etc., especially in order to trick or entertain somebody
examples: He made up some excuse about his daughter being sick.
I told the kids a story, making it up as I went along.
You made that up!

meanings.def: to complete a number or an amount required
examples: We need one more person to make up a team.

meanings.def: to replace something that has been lost; to compensate for something
examples: Can I leave early this afternoon and make up the time tomorrow?

meanings.def: to prepare a medicine by mixing different things together
to prepare a bed for use; to create a temporary bed
examples: We made up the bed in the spare room.
They made up a bed for me on the sofa.

meanings.def: to clean a hotel room and make the bed
examples: The maid asked if she could make up the room.
They had forgotten to make up the room.

meanings.def: to end an argument with somebody and become friends again
examples: Why don't you two kiss and make up?
Has he made it up with her yet?
Have they made it up yet?

meanings.def: coloured substances used on the skin to make yourself look more attractive or to change your appearance
examples: eye make-up
to put on your make-up
She never wears make-up.
a make-up artist (= a person whose job is to put make-up on other people)
in make-up The actor has to spend three hours in make-up (= having make-up put on) each morning before filming can start.
publicity photos of the actor in make-up (= wearing make-up) for the role
He was given an Oscar for his make-up work on the film.
I never wear make-up.
She was checking her make-up in the mirror.
You don't wear full make-up to go swimming.
a tearful girl with make-up running down her face
the make-up effects for the film

meanings.def: the different qualities that combine to form somebody’s character or being
examples: Jealousy is not part of his make-up.
The final act exposes the fatal flaws in his make-up.
a person’s genetic make-up
The report studies the psychological make-up of a serial killer.

meanings.def: the different things, people, etc. that combine to form something; the way in which they combine
examples: the make-up of a TV audience
Ireland did show up a number of flaws in the England team's make-up.
(specialist) the page make-up of a text (= the way in which the words and pictures are arranged on a page)

meanings.def: a special exam taken by students who missed or failed an earlier one
